metadata.title: Australian Government Information Security manual
metadata.remarks:
This is not an official version of the Australian Government Information Security Manual.

Find the official versions here: https://www.cyber.gov.au/acsc/view-all-content/ism
This content was generated using scrips/ISM/ISM.py

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using outsourced cloud services, only those listed on the ACSC’s Certified Cloud Services List are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using outsourced cloud services for highly classified information, public clouds are not used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using an outsourced cloud service not listed on the ACSC’s Certified Cloud Services List, or for highly classified information, the ACSC is notified in writing at the earliest opportunity, and certainly before entering into or renewing a contract.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using an outsourced information technology service, or cloud service not listed on the ACSC’s Certified Cloud Services List, a service provider whose systems are located in Australia is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any security controls associated with the protection of information entrusted to a service provider are documented in contract provisions, a memorandum of understanding or an equivalent formal agreement between parties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An organisation’s systems and information are not accessed or administered by a service provider from outside Australian borders unless a contractual arrangement exists between the organisation and the service provider to do so.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When entering into a contractual arrangement for outsourced information technology or cloud services, contractual ownership over an organisation’s data is explicitly retained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A review of suppliers, including their country of origin, is performed before obtaining software, hardware or services to assess the potential increase to an organisation’s security risk profile.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The latest version (N), or N-1 version, of an operating system is used for Standard Operating Environments (SOEs).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When developing a Microsoft Windows SOE, the 64-bit version of the operating system is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ACSC and vendor guidance is implemented to assist in hardening the configuration of operating systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Default operating system accounts are disabled, renamed or have their passphrase changed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unneeded operating system accounts, software, components, services and functionality are removed or disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Standard users are prevented from running all script execution engines shipped with Microsoft Windows including Windows Script Host (cscript.exe and wscript.exe), powershell.exe, powershell_ise.exe, cmd.exe, wmic.exe and Microsoft HTML Application Host (mshta.exe).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Local administrator accounts are disabled; alternatively, passphrases that are random and unique for each device’s local administrator account are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unique domain accounts with local administrative privileges, but without domain administrative privileges, are used for workstation and server management.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users do not have the ability to install, uninstall or disable software.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An application whitelisting solution is implemented on all workstations to restrict the execution of executables, software libraries, scripts and installers to an approved set.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An application whitelisting solution is implemented on Active Directory servers, email servers and other servers handling user authentication to restrict the execution of executables, software libraries, scripts and installers to an approved set.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All users (with the exception of privileged users when performing specific administrative activities) cannot disable, bypass or be exempted from application whitelisting mechanisms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Application whitelisting is implemented using cryptographic hash rules, publisher certificate rules or path rules.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When implementing application whitelisting using publisher certificate rules, both publisher names and product names are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When implementing application whitelisting using path rules, file system permissions are configured to prevent unauthorised modification of folder and file permissions, folder contents (including adding new files) and individual files that are approved to execute.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Application whitelisting solutions are configured to generate event logs for failed execution attempts, including information such as the name of the blocked file, the date/time stamp and the username of the user attempting to execute the file.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If supported, the latest version of Microsoft’s EMET is implemented on workstations and servers and configured with both operating system mitigation measures and application-specific mitigation measures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If supported, Microsoft's 'Exploit protection' functionality is implemented on workstations and servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A HIPS is implemented on workstations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A HIPS is implemented on high value servers such as authentication servers, Domain Name System (DNS) servers, web servers, file servers and email servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A software firewall is implemented on workstations and servers to limit both inbound and outbound network connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Antivirus software is implemented on workstations and servers and configured with:
§ signature-based detection enabled and set to a high level
§ heuristic-based detection enabled and set to a high level
§ detection signatures checked for currency and updated on at least a daily basis
§ automatic and regular scanning configured for all fixed disks and removable media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Antivirus software has reputation rating functionality enabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Endpoint device control software is implemented on workstations and servers to prevent unauthorised devices from being used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Applications are chosen from vendors that have made a commitment to secure development and maintenance practices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The latest releases of key business applications such as office productivity suites, PDF viewers, web browsers, common web browser plugins, email clients and software platforms are used when present within SOEs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The latest releases of web server software, server applications that store important data, and other internet-accessible server applications are used when present within SOEs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ACSC and vendor guidance is implemented to assist in hardening the configuration of Microsoft Office, web browsers and PDF readers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browsers are configured to block or disable support for Flash content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browsers are configured to block web advertisements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browsers are configured to block Java from the Internet.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office is configured to disable support for Flash content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office is configured to prevent activation of Object Linking and Embedding packages.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any unrequired functionality in Microsoft Office, web browsers and PDF readers is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office macros are only allowed to execute in documents from Trusted Locations where write access is limited to personnel whose role is to vet and approve macros.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office macros in documents originating from the Internet are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office macro security settings cannot be changed by users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All users are uniquely identifiable and authenticated on each occasion that access is granted to a system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where systems contain nationality releasability information, all users who are foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, are uniquely identifiable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where systems contain AUSTEO or AGAO information, all users who are foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, are uniquely identifiable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security controls used to identify users who are foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, include identification measures that specify their nationality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of shared user accounts is controlled and auditable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A numerical password is not used as the sole method of authenticating a user.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Passphrases used as the sole method of authentication enforce a minimum of 13 alphabetic characters; or a minimum of 10 characters consisting of at least three of the following character sets:
§ lowercase alphabetic characters (a-z)
§ uppercase alphabetic characters (A-Z)
§ numeric characters (0-9)
§ special characters.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Passphrases used as the sole method of authentication enforce a minimum of 15 alphabetic characters; or a minimum of 11 characters consisting of at least three of the following character sets:
§ lowercase alphabetic characters (a-z)
§ uppercase alphabetic characters (A-Z)
§ numeric characters (0-9)
§ special characters.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Passphrase management practices:
§ ensure that passphrases are changed at least every 90 days
§ prevent passphrases from being changed by a user more than once a day
§ prevent passphrases from being reused within eight passphrase changes
§ prevent the use of sequential passphrases where possible
§ prevent passphrases being stored in cleartext.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When systems cannot be configured to enforce passphrase complexity and management practices, passphrases are checked by alternative means for compliance with passphrase policies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate standard users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate privileged users and other positions of trust.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate all users of remote access solutions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate all users when accessing important data repositories.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication uses passphrases with a minimum of six alphabetic characters and one of the following authentication factors: Universal 2nd Factor (U2F) security keys, physical one-time personal identification number (OTP) tokens, biometrics or smartcards.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When multi-factor authentication is implemented, none of the authentication factors on their own can be used for single-factor authentication to another system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: LAN Manager is disabled for passphrase authentication on workstations and servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Accounts are locked after a maximum of five failed logon attempts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Repeated account lockouts are investigated before reauthorising access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users provide sufficient evidence to verify their identity when requesting a passphrase reset.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Passphrases resets are:
§ random for each individual reset
§ not reused when resetting multiple accounts
§ not based on a single dictionary word
§ not based on another identifying factor, such as the user’s name or the date.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication information is stored separately from a system to which it grants access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication information stored or communicated by a system is protected from unauthorised access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Systems are configured with a session or screen lock that:
§ activates after a maximum of 15 minutes of user inactivity or if manually activated by the user
§ completely conceals all information on the screen
§ ensures that the screen does not enter a power saving state before the screen or session lock is activated
§ requires the user to reauthenticate to unlock the system
§ denies users the ability to disable the session or screen locking mechanism.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Systems have a logon banner that requires users to acknowledge and accept their security responsibilities before access is granted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal advice is sought on the exact wording of logon banners.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A policy governing the use of telephone systems is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of the permitted sensitivity or classification of information that can be discussed over both internal and external telephone systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of security risks posed by non-secure telephone systems in areas where sensitive or classified conversations can occur.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When permitting different levels of conversation for different kinds of connections, telephone systems give a visual indication of what kind of connection has been made.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Telephone systems used for sensitive or classified conversations encrypt all traffic that passes over external systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cordless telephone systems are not used for sensitive or classified conversations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cordless telephone systems are not used in conjunction with secure telephony devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Speakerphones are not used on telephone systems in TOP SECRET areas unless the telephone system is located in a room rated as audio secure, the room is audio secure during conversations and only personnel involved in discussions are present in the room.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In PROTECTED areas, off-hook audio protection features are used on all telephones that are not authorised for the transmission of PROTECTED information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In SECRET areas, push-to-talk handsets are used on all telephones that are not authorised for the transmission of SECRET information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas, push-to-talk handsets are used on all telephones that are not authorised for the transmission of TOP SECRET information.

groups.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0546

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a requirement exists to implement a firewall in a gateway, and video conferencing or IP telephony traffic passes through the gateway, a video or voice-aware firewall is used.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0547

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Video conferencing and IP telephony signalling and data is encrypted.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0548

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Video conferencing and IP telephony functions are established using secure signalling and data protocols.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0554

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An encrypted and non-replayable two-way authentication scheme is used for call authentication and authorisation.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0553

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication and authorisation is used for all actions on a video conferencing network, including call setup and changing settings.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0555

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication and authorisation is used for all actions on a IP telephony network, including registering a new IP phone, changing phone users, changing settings and accessing voicemail.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0551

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
IP telephony is configured such that:
§ IP phones authenticate themselves to the call controller upon registration
§ auto-registration is disabled and only a whitelist of authorised devices is allowed to access the network
§ unauthorised devices are blocked by default
§ all unused and prohibited functionality is disabled.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0552

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
IP telephony is configured such that:
§ IP phones authenticate themselves to the call controller upon registration
§ auto-registration is disabled and only a whitelist of authorised devices is allowed to access the network
§ unauthorised devices are blocked by default
§ all unused and prohibited functionality is disabled.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 1014

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individual logins are used for IP phones.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0549

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Video conferencing and IP telephony traffic is separated physically or logically from other data traffic.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0550

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Video conferencing and IP telephony traffic is separated physically or logically from other data traffic.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0556

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Workstations are not connected to video conferencing units or IP phones unless the workstation or the device uses VLANs or similar mechanisms to maintain separation between video conferencing, IP telephony and other data traffic.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0557

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Workstations are not connected to video conferencing units or IP phones unless the workstation or the device uses VLANs or similar mechanisms to maintain separation between video conferencing, IP telephony and other data traffic.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 1015

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Traditional analog phones are used in lobby and shared areas.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0558

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If IP phones are used in lobby and shared areas, their ability to access data networks, voicemail and directory services are prevented.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 0559

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microphones (including headsets and USB handsets) and webcams are not used with non-SECRET workstations in SECRET areas.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 1450

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microphones (including headsets and USB handsets) and webcams are not used with non-TOP SECRET workstations in TOP SECRET areas.

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony 1019

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A denial of service response plan is developed and implemented that includes:
§ how to identify signs of a denial of service
§ how to identify the source of a denial of service
§ how capabilities can be maintained during a denial of service
§ what actions can be taken to clear a denial of service.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A policy governing the use of fax machines and MFDs is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Separate fax machines or MFDs are used for sending sensitive or classified fax messages and all other fax messages.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When sending fax messages, the fax message is encrypted to an appropriate level to be communicated over unsecured telecommunications infrastructure or the PSTN.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The sender of a fax message makes arrangements for the receiver to collect the fax message as soon as possible after it is received and notify the sender if the fax message does not arrive in an agreed amount of time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A direct connection from an MFD to a digital telephone system is not enabled unless the telephone system is authorised to operate at the same sensitivity or classification as the computer network to which the MFD is connected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Where MFDs connected to computer networks have the ability to communicate via a gateway to another network:
§ each MFD applies user identification, authentication and audit functions for all information communicated by that device
§ security controls are of similar strength to those specified for workstations on that network
§ each gateway can identify and filter information in accordance with the security controls for the export of data via a gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: MFDs connected to computer networks are not used to copy documents above the sensitivity or classification of the connected network.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Fax machines and MFDs are located in areas where their use can be observed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Software development, testing and production environments are segregated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Development and modification of software only takes place in development environments.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information in production environments is not used in testing or development environments unless the testing or development environments are secured to the same level as the production environments.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unauthorised access to the authoritative source for software is prevented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Threat modelling and other secure design techniques are used to ensure that threats to software and mitigations to those threats are identified and accounted for.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Platform-specific secure programming practices are used when developing software, including using the lowest privilege needed to achieve a task, checking return values of all system calls and validating all inputs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Software is tested for security vulnerabilities by software developers, as well as an independent party, before it is used in a production environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Robust web application frameworks are used to aid in the development of secure web applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Validation and/or sanitisation is performed on all input handled by a web application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Output encoding is performed on all output produced by a web application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browser-based security controls are implemented for web applications in order to help protect both web applications and their users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The OWASP Development Guide is followed when developing web applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Evaluated products are installed, configured, administered and operated in accordance with vendor guidance and evaluation documentation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: High assurance ICT equipment is installed, configured, administered and operated in accordance with guidance produced by the ACSC.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: High assurance ICT equipment is only operated in an evaluated configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If procuring an evaluated product, a product that has completed a protection profile evaluation is selected in preference to one that has completed an EAL-based evaluation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Evaluated products are delivered in a manner consistent with any delivery procedures defined in associated evaluation documentation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When procuring high assurance ICT equipment, the ACSC is contacted for any equipment-specific delivery procedures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A policy governing the management of mobile devices is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Mobile Device Management solution is used to ensure mobile device management policy is applied to all mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices do not process, store or communicate TOP SECRET information unless explicitly approved by the ACSC to do so.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel accessing official information using a privately-owned mobile device use an organisation approved platform, an appropriate security configuration, and have enforced separation of official and personal information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel accessing classified information using a privately-owned mobile device use an ACSC approved platform, a security configuration in accordance with ACSC hardening guidance, and have enforced separation of classified and personal information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privately-owned mobile devices do not access highly classified systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Prior to allowing privately-owned mobile devices to connect to an organisation’s systems, legal advice is sought.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel accessing official information using an organisation-owned mobile device use an organisation approved platform with an appropriate security configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel accessing classified information using an organisation-owned mobile device use an ACSC approved platform with a security configuration in accordance with ACSC hardening guidance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All information on mobile devices is encrypted using at least an Australian Signals Directorate (ASD) Approved Cryptographic Algorithm (AACA).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices used to communicate sensitive or classified information over public network infrastructure use encryption approved for communicating such information over public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The range of Bluetooth communications between mobile devices and other Bluetooth devices is restricted to less than 10 metres by using class 2 or class 3 Bluetooth devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth functionality is not enabled on highly classified mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices are configured to remain undiscoverable to other Bluetooth devices except during Bluetooth pairing.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth pairing is performed using Bluetooth version 2.1 or later.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth pairing is performed in a manner such that connections are only made between intended Bluetooth devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth pairings are removed from mobile devices when there is no longer a requirement for their use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The configuration of mobile devices is controlled in the same manner as devices in the office environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices prevent personnel from installing or uninstalling applications once provisioned.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are prevented from disabling security functions on mobile devices once provisioned.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile carriers that are able to provide timely security updates for mobile devices are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices are able to accept security updates from mobile carriers as soon as they become available.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browsing from mobile devices is conducted through an organisation’s internet gateway rather than via a direct connection to the Internet.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When accessing an organisation system via a VPN connection, split tunnelling is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A policy governing the use of mobile devices is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of the sensitivity or classification permitted for voice and data communications when using mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Paging, Multimedia Message Service (MMS), Short Message Service (SMS) or instant messaging apps are not used to communicate sensitive or classified information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Sensitive or classified information is not accessed or communicated in public locations unless care is taken to reduce the chance of the screen of a mobile device being observed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privacy filters are applied to the screens of highly classified mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices are kept under continual direct supervision.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices are carried in a secured state when not being actively used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If unable to apply encryption to mobile devices that is suitable for them to be carried through areas not authorised to process the information stored on them, they are physically transferred in a security briefcase or an approved multi-use satchel, pouch or transit bag.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Emergency sanitisation procedures are developed for mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a cryptographic zeroise or sanitise function is provided for cryptographic keys on highly classified mobile devices, the function is used as part of emergency sanitisation procedures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: User education and the implementation of security controls are conducted prior to personnel travelling overseas with mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When travelling overseas with mobile devices and media, personnel retain control over them at all times, this includes by not placing them in checked-in luggage or leaving them unattended for any period of time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Personnel take the following precautions when travelling overseas with mobile devices:
§ avoiding storing authentication details or tokens and passphrases with mobile devices
§ avoiding connecting to open Wi-Fi networks
§ clearing web browsers after each browsing session including history, cache, cookies and temporary files
§ encrypting emails where possible
§ ensuring login pages are encrypted before entering passphrases
§ avoiding connecting to untrusted computers or inserting removable media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If personnel are requested to decrypt mobile devices for inspection by customs personnel, or their devices leave their possession at any time, they report the potential compromise of information to their organisation as soon as possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All passphrases associated with mobile devices are changed upon returning from overseas.

groups.title: Guidelines for data transfers and content filtering

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data transfers are performed in accordance with approved procedures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users transferring data to and from a system are held accountable through policies and procedures for the data they transfer.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Trusted sources are a strictly limited number of personnel that have been identified using a security risk assessment and have been authorised as such by an organisation’s CISO.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A trusted source makes an informed decision to sign all data authorised for export from a security domain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All data transferred to a system of a lesser sensitivity or classification is reviewed and approved by a trusted source.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data imported to a system is scanned for malicious and active content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data imported to a system is scanned for malicious and active content, undergoes data format checks and logging, and is monitored to detect overuse/unusual usage patterns.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When exporting data, protective marking checks are undertaken.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
When exporting data, the following activities are undertaken:
§ protective marking checks
§ data format checks and logging
§ monitoring to detect overuse/unusual usage patterns
§ limitations on data types and sizes
§ keyword searches on all textual data.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures are developed to prevent AUSTEO and AGAO data in both textual and non-textual formats from being exported to foreign systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When exporting data from an AUSTEO or AGAO system, keyword searches are undertaken on all textual data and any identified data is quarantined until reviewed and approved for release by a trusted source other than the originator.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data exported from each security domain, including through a gateway, is only permitted once the classification has been assessed including a protective marking check.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When importing data to each security domain, by any means including through a gateway, the complete data transfer logs are audited at least monthly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When exporting data out of each security domain, by any means including through a gateway, the complete data transfer logs are audited at least monthly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When importing content to a security domain, including through a gateway, monthly audits of the imported content are performed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When exporting content out of a security domain, including through a gateway, monthly audits of the exported content are performed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When importing data into a security domain, by any means including a CDS, the data is filtered by a content filter designed for that purpose.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content filters deployed in CDS are subject to rigorous security assessment to ensure they mitigate content-based threats and cannot be bypassed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All suspicious, malicious and active content is blocked from entering a security domain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any data identified by a content filtering process as suspicious is blocked until reviewed and approved for transfer by a trusted source other than the originator.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Email and web content entering a security domain is automatically run in a dynamic malware analysis sandbox to detect suspicious behaviour.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content validation is performed on all data passing through a content filter with content which fails content validation blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content validation is performed on all data passing through a content filter with content which fails content validation blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content conversion is performed for all ingress or egress data transiting a security domain boundary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content sanitisation is performed on suitable file types if content conversion is not appropriate for data transiting a security domain boundary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Antivirus scanning, using multiple different scanning engines, is performed on all content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The contents from archive/container files are extracted and subjected to content filter checks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Controlled inspection of archive/container files is performed to ensure that content filter performance or availability is not adversely affected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Files that cannot be inspected are blocked and generate an alert or notification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A whitelist of permitted content types is created and enforced based on business requirements and the results of a security risk assessment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A whitelist of permitted content types is created and enforced based on business requirements and the results of a security risk assessment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The integrity of content is verified where applicable and blocked if verification fails.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If data is signed, the signature is validated before the data is exported.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All encrypted content, traffic and data is decrypted and inspected to allow content filtering.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures for the destruction of media are developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following media types are destroyed prior to disposal as they cannot be sanitised:
§ microfiche and microfilm
§ optical discs
§ programmable read-only memory
§ read-only memory
§ other types of media that cannot be sanitised
§ faulty media that cannot be successfully sanitised.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SCEC or ASIO approved equipment is used when destroying media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using degaussers to destroy media, degaussers evaluated by the United States’ National Security Agency or certified by the United Kingdom’s National Cyber Security Centre are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Equipment that is capable of reducing microform to a fine powder, with resultant particles not showing more than five consecutive characters per particle upon microscopic inspection, is used to destroy microfiche and microfilm.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: One of the methods in the following table is used to destroy media. (See source document for referenced table)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The resulting waste for all destruction methods, except for furnace/incinerator and degausser, is stored and handled as per the following table. (See source document for referenced table)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A degausser of sufficient field strength for the coercivity of the magnetic media is used, with the field strength being checked at regular intervals.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A degausser capable of the magnetic orientation (longitudinal or perpendicular) of the magnetic media is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any product-specific directions provided by degausser manufacturers are followed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The destruction of media is performed under the supervision of at least one person cleared to the sensitivity or classification of the media being destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel supervising the destruction of media supervise the handling of the media to the point of destruction and ensure that the destruction is completed successfully.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The destruction of accountable material is performed under the supervision of at least two personnel cleared to the sensitivity or classification of the media being destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel supervising the destruction of accountable media supervise the handling of the material to the point of destruction, ensure that the destruction is completed successfully and sign a destruction certificate afterwards.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When outsourcing the destruction of media to an external destruction service, a National Association for Information Destruction AAA certified destruction service with endorsements, as specified in ASIO’s PSC-167, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The destruction of TOP SECRET media or accountable material is not outsourced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If possible, media is sanitised prior to transportation to an off-site location for destruction.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures for the sanitisation of media are developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Volatile media is sanitised by removing power from the media for at least 10 minutes or by overwriting all locations on the media with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Volatile media is sanitised by overwriting the media at least once in its entirety with a random pattern, followed by a read back for verification, and then followed by removing power from the media for at least 10 minutes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, highly classified volatile media retains its classification if it stored static data for an extended period of time, or had data repeatedly stored on or written to the same memory location for an extended period of time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The host-protected area and device configuration overlay table of non-volatile magnetic media is reset prior to sanitisation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Non-volatile magnetic media is sanitised by booting from separate media to the media being sanitised and then overwriting the media at least once (or three times if pre-2001 or under 15 Gigabytes) in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The ATA secure erase command is used where available, in addition to using block overwriting software, to ensure the growth defects table (g-list) is overwritten.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, highly classified non-volatile magnetic media retains its classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Non-volatile EPROM media is sanitised by erasing the media in accordance with the manufacturer’s specification, increasing the specified ultraviolet erasure time by a factor of three, then overwriting the media at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Non-volatile EEPROM media is sanitised by overwriting the media at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, highly classified non-volatile EPROM and EEPROM media retains its classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Non-volatile flash memory media is sanitised by overwriting the media at least twice in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, highly classified non-volatile flash memory media retains its classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All media is sanitised prior to reuse.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a consumer guide for evaluated encryption software exists, the sanitisation and post-sanitisation requirements stated in the consumer guide are followed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures for the disposal of media are developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to handle media, or its waste, as ‘publicly releasable’ before it is released into the public domain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Labels and markings indicating the classification, codewords, caveats, owner, system, network, or any other marking that can associate media with its original use, are removed prior to disposal.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A removable media policy is developed and implemented that includes:
§ details of the removable media authority within the organisation
§ types of media permitted within the organisation
§ processes for media registration and auditing
§ processes for media classification and labelling
§ processes for the use of media
§ processes for the sanitisation/destruction and disposal of media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is classified to the highest sensitivity or classification stored on the media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any media connected to a system is classified as the same sensitivity or classification as the system, unless the media is read-only, the media is inserted into a read-only device or the system has a mechanism through which read-only access can be assured.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is reclassified if information copied onto the media is of a higher sensitivity or classification than the information already on the media, or information stored on the media is subject to a classification upgrade.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If reclassifying media to a lower sensitivity or classification, the reclassification of all information on the media has been approved by the originator, or the media has been appropriately sanitised/destroyed and a formal administrative decision has been made to reclassify it.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media, with the exception of internally mounted fixed media within ICT equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is not used with systems that are not authorised to process, store or communicate the sensitivity or classification of information on it.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any automatic execution features for media are disabled in the operating system of systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unauthorised media is prevented from connecting to systems via the use of device access control software, disabling connection ports, or by physical means.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is prevented from being written to via the use of device access control software if there is no business requirement for its use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: External interface connections that allow DMA are disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is handled in a manner suitable for its sensitivity or classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is encrypted with at least an Australian Signals Directorate (ASD) Approved Cryptographic Algorithm (AACA).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When transferring data manually between two systems belonging to different security domains, write-once media is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When not in use, media is stored in a manner suitable for its sensitivity or classification.

groups.title: Guidelines for connecting networks and security domains

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A firewall is used between official networks and public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated firewall is used between classified networks and public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A firewall is used between official networks belonging to different security domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated firewall is used between official and classified networks, and classified networks belonging to different security domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirement to use a firewall as part of gateway infrastructure is met by both parties independently; shared ICT equipment does not satisfy the requirements of both parties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to the firewall between networks of different security domains, an evaluated firewall is used between an AUSTEO or AGAO network and a foreign network.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to the firewall between networks of different security domains, an evaluated firewall is used between an AUSTEO or AGAO network and another Australian controlled network.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between official and classified systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A high assurance peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between official or classified systems and highly classified systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated, preferably high assurance, peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between systems of different classifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between systems belonging to different security domains at the same classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated peripheral switch is used when accessing a system containing AUSTEO or AGAO information and a system of the same classification that is not authorised to process the same caveat.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated diode is used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between official or classified networks and public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A high assurance diode is used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between classified networks and public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated diode is used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between official and classified networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A high assurance diode is used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between official or classified networks where the highest system is SECRET or above.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated diode is used between an AUSTEO or AGAO network and a foreign network at the same classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated diode is used between an AUSTEO or AGAO network and another Australian controlled network at the same classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A diode (or server connected to the diode) deployed to control data flow in unidirectional gateways monitors the volume of the data being transferred.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When connecting a highly classified network to any other network from a different security domain, a CDS is implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When designing and deploying a CDS, the ACSC is notified and consulted; and directions provided by the ACSC are complied with.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When introducing additional connectivity to a CDS, such as adding a new gateway to a common network, the ACSC is consulted on the impact to the security of the CDS; and directions provided by the ACSC are complied with.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CDS between highly classified networks and any other network implement isolated upward and downward network paths.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CDS between highly classified networks and any other network implement protocol breaks at each layer of the OSI model.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CDS between highly classified networks and any other network implement content filtering and separate independent security-enforcing components for upward and downward data flows.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All security-relevant events generated by a CDS are logged and regularly analysed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A representative sample of security events generated by a CDS, relating to the enforcement of data transfer policies, is taken at least every 3 months and assessed against the security policies that the CDS is responsible for enforcing between security domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All systems are protected from systems in other security domains by one or more gateways or CDS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All connections between security domains implement mechanisms to inspect and filter data flows for the transport and higher layers as defined in the OSI model.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Gateways:
§ are the only communications paths into and out of internal networks
§ by default, deny all connections into and out of the network
§ allow only explicitly authorised connections
§ apply the guidance in the Guidelines for data transfers and content filtering
§ are managed via a secure path isolated from all connected networks (physically at the gateway or on a dedicated administration network)
§ provide sufficient logging and audit capabilities to detect cyber security incidents, attempted intrusions and overuse/unusual usage patterns
§ provide real-time alerts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
All gateways connecting networks in different security domains are operated and maintained such that they:
§ filter all network traffic attempting to enter the gateway and log subsequently permitted traffic
§ log network traffic attempting to leave the gateway
§ are configured to save event logs to a separate secure log server
§ are protected by authentication, logging and auditing of all physical and logical access to gateway components
§ have all security controls tested to verify their effectiveness after any changes to their configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Demilitarised zones are used to broker access to services accessed by external entities, and mechanisms are applied to mediate internal and external access to less-trusted services hosted in these demilitarised zones.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A security risk assessment is performed on gateways and their configuration before their implementation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A security risk assessment is performed on all systems before they are connected to a gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All system owners of systems connected via a gateway understand and accept security risks associated with the gateway and any connected security domains, including those connected via a cascaded connection.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The security architecture of a gateway, and security risks associated with all connected security domains, including those connected via a cascaded connection, is reviewed at least annually.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any associated security risk assessments are updated before changes are made to a gateway to ensure all relevant security risks have been documented and accepted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All changes to a gateway architecture are considered prior to implementation, documented and assessed in accordance with the organisation’s change management process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Gateways are subject to rigorous testing, performed at irregular intervals no more than six months apart, to determine the strength of security controls.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All users are trained on the secure use of gateways before access to systems connected to a gateway is granted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to gateway and CDS administration functions is limited to the minimum roles and privileges to support the gateway securely.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System administrators are formally trained to manage gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All system administrators of gateways are cleared to access the highest level of information communicated or processed by the gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All system administrators of gateways that process Australian Eyes Only (AUSTEO) or Australian Government Access Only (AGAO) information are Australian nationals.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Roles for the administration of gateways are separated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Roles for the administration of gateways are separated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For gateways between networks in different security domains, a formal arrangement exists whereby any shared components are managed by the system managers of the highest security domain or by a mutually agreed third party.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once connectivity is established, system owners become information stakeholders for all connected security domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once connectivity is established, system owners become information stakeholders for all connected security domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users and services accessing networks through gateways are authenticated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only users and services authenticated and authorised to a gateway can use the gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used for access to gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment accessing networks through gateways is authenticated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A policy governing appropriate web usage is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All web access, including that by internal servers, is conducted through a web proxy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A web proxy authenticates users and provides logging that includes the following details about websites accessed:
§ address (uniform resource locator)
§ time/date
§ user
§ amount of data uploaded and downloaded
§ internal and external Internet Protocol (IP) addresses.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The installation of web browser add-ons is restricted to organisation approved add-ons.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
If permitting TLS through internet gateways, either of the following approaches is implemented:
§ a solution that decrypts and inspects TLS traffic as per content filtering security controls
§ a whitelist specifying the addresses (uniform resource locators) to which encrypted connections are permitted, with all other addresses blocked or decrypted and inspected as per content filtering security controls.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal advice is sought regarding the inspection of TLS traffic by internet gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Whitelisting is implemented for all Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) traffic communicated through internet gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using a whitelist on internet gateways to specify the external addresses to which connections are permitted, it specifies whitelisted addresses by domain name or IP address.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If websites are not whitelisted, categories are implemented for all websites and prohibited and uncategorised websites are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If whitelisting of websites is not implemented, blacklisting of websites is implemented to prevent access to known malicious websites.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If blacklisting websites, the blacklist is updated on a daily basis to ensure that it remains effective.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Attempts to access a website through its IP address instead of through its domain name are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Dynamic domains and other domains where domain names can be registered anonymously for free are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A web content filter is used to filter potentially harmful web-based content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Client-side active content, such as Java, is restricted to a whitelist of approved websites which may be the same as the HTTP whitelist or a separate active content whitelist.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web content filtering controls are applied to outbound web traffic where appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber security incident responsibilities and procedures are detailed for each system in their security documentation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Cyber security incidents are recorded in a register with the following information:
§ the date the cyber security incident occurred
§ the date the cyber security incident was discovered
§ a description of the cyber security incident
§ any actions taken in response to the cyber security incident
§ to whom the cyber security incident was reported.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a data spill occurs, information owners are advised and access to the information is restricted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
When malicious code is detected, the following steps are taken to handle the infection:
§ the infected system is isolated
§ all previously connected systems, including any media used in the period leading up to the infection, are scanned for signs of infection and isolated if necessary
§ antivirus software is used to remove the infection from infected systems and media
§ if possible, any previously infected system is restored from a known good backup or rebuilt.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal advice is sought before allowing targeted cyber intrusion activity to continue on a system for the purpose of collecting further information or evidence.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Post-incident analysis is performed for successful targeted cyber intrusions; this includes storing full network traffic for at least seven days after a targeted cyber intrusion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The integrity of evidence gathered during an investigation is maintained by investigators recording all of their actions and ensuring raw audit trails are copied onto media for archiving.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber security personnel have access to sufficient data sources and tools to ensure that any security alerts generated by systems are investigated and that systems and data sources are able to be searched for key indicators of compromise including but not limited to IP addresses, domains and file hashes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber security incidents are reported to an organisation’s CISO, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When organisations use outsourced information technology or cloud services, their service providers report all cyber security incidents to the organisation’s CISO, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber security incidents are reported to the ACSC using the CSIR scheme.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where possible, maintenance and repairs of ICT equipment is carried out on-site by an appropriately cleared technician.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The ACSC’s approval is sought before undertaking any repairs to high assurance ICT equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an uncleared technician is used to undertake maintenance or repairs of ICT equipment, the ICT equipment and associated media is sanitised before maintenance or repair work is undertaken.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
If an uncleared technician is used to undertake maintenance or repairs of ICT equipment, the technician is escorted by someone who:
§ is appropriately cleared and briefed
§ takes due care to ensure that information is not disclosed
§ takes all responsible measures to ensure the integrity of the ICT equipment
§ has the authority to direct the technician
§ is sufficiently familiar with the ICT equipment to understand the work being performed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment maintained or repaired off-site is done so in accordance with the physical transfer and storage requirements for the sensitivity or classification of the ICT equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment maintained or repaired off-site is treated as per the requirements for the sensitivity or classification of the area that the ICT equipment will be returned to.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures for the sanitisation and disposal of ICT equipment are developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When disposing of ICT equipment containing media, the ICT equipment is sanitised by sanitising the media within the ICT equipment, removing the media from the ICT equipment or destroying the ICT equipment in its entirety.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Labels and markings indicating the classification, codewords, caveats, owner, system, network, or any other marking that can associate the ICT equipment with its original use, are removed prior to disposal.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to handle ICT equipment, or its waste, as ‘publicly releasable’ before it is released into the public domain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If disposing of high assurance ICT equipment or TEMPEST-rated ICT equipment, the ACSC is contacted for requirements relating to its secure disposal.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed or stored AUSTEO or AGAO information is sanitised in situ where possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed or stored AUSTEO or AGAO information that cannot be sanitised in situ is returned to Australia for destruction.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least three pages of random text with no blank areas are printed on each colour printer cartridge or MFD print drum.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: MFD print drums and image transfer rollers are inspected and destroyed if there is remnant toner which cannot be removed or if a print is visible on the image transfer roller.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Printer and MFD platens are inspected and destroyed if any images are retained on the platen.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Printers and MFDs are checked to ensure no pages are trapped in the paper path due to a paper jam.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When unable to sanitise printer cartridges or MFD print drums, they are destroyed as per electrostatic memory devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Printer ribbons in printers and MFDs are removed and destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Televisions and computer monitors with minor burn-in or image persistence are sanitised by displaying a solid white image on the screen for an extended period of time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Televisions and computer monitors that cannot be sanitised are destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Memory in network devices is sanitised using the following processes, in order of preference:
§ following consumer guides from the ACSC’s Evaluated Products List
§ following device-specific advice produced by the ACSC
§ following vendor sanitisation guidance
§ if guidance is unavailable, performing a full reset and loading of a dummy configuration file.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The paper tray of the fax machine is removed, and a fax message with a minimum length of four pages is transmitted, before the paper tray is re-installed to allow a fax summary page to be printed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Fax machines are checked to ensure no pages are trapped in the paper path due to a paper jam.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment is classified based on the highest sensitivity or classification of information that it is approved for processing, storing or communicating.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment, with the exception of high assurance ICT equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC)’s approval is sought before applying labels to external surfaces of high assurance ICT equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An event logging strategy is developed and implemented covering events to be logged, logging facilities to be used, event log retention periods and how event logs will be protected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A centralised logging facility is implemented and systems are configured to save event logs to the centralised logging facility as soon as possible after each event occurs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An accurate time source is established and used consistently across systems and network devices to assist with the correlation of events.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For any system requiring authentication, logon, failed logon and logoff events are logged.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following events are logged for operating systems:
§ access to important data and processes
§ application crashes and any error messages
§ attempts to use special privileges
§ changes to accounts
§ changes to security policy
§ changes to system configurations
§ Domain Name System (DNS) and Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) requests
§ failed attempts to access data and system resources
§ service failures and restarts
§ system startup and shutdown
§ transfer of data to external media
§ user or group management
§ use of special privileges.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following events are logged for web applications:
§ attempted access that is denied
§ crashes and any error messages
§ search queries initiated by users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following events are logged for databases:
§ access to particularly important information
§ addition of new users, especially privileged users
§ any query containing comments
§ any query containing multiple embedded queries
§ any query or database alerts or failures
§ attempts to elevate privileges
§ attempted access that is successful or unsuccessful
§ changes to the database structure
§ changes to user roles or database permissions
§ database administrator actions
§ database logons and logoffs
§ modifications to data
§ use of executable commands.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For each event logged, the date and time of the event, the relevant user or process, the event description, and the ICT equipment involved are recorded.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Event logs are protected from unauthorised access, modification and deletion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Event logs are retained for a minimum of 7 years in accordance with the National Archives of Australia’s Administrative Functions Disposal Authority publication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DNS and proxy logs are retained for at least 18 months.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Event log auditing procedures are developed and implemented covering the scope and schedule of audits, what constitutes a violation of security policy, and actions to be taken when violations are detected, including reporting requirements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Events are correlated across event logs to prioritise audits and focus investigations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A vulnerability management strategy is developed and implemented that includes:
§ conducting vulnerability assessments and penetration tests for systems throughout their life cycle to identify security vulnerabilities
§ analysing identified security vulnerabilities to determine their potential impact and appropriate mitigations or treatments based on effectiveness, cost and existing security controls
§ using a risk-based approach to prioritise the implementation of identified mitigations or treatments
§ monitoring information on new or updated security vulnerabilities in operating systems, software and ICT equipment as well as other elements which may adversely impact the security of a system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Vulnerability assessments and penetration tests are conducted by suitably skilled personnel before a system is deployed, after a significant change to a system, and at least annually or as specified by the system owner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Systems have a SSP that includes security controls from this document based on its classification, functionality and the technologies it is implementing with additional security controls included based on security risks identified during a security risk assessment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Systems have SOPs that cover the following:
§ system administration and maintenance activities, such as managing backups and user accounts
§ software and hardware configuration changes, such as patches, updates and upgrades
§ the acquisition, support and disposal of assets
§ the labelling, registering and mustering of assets.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Systems have an IRP that covers the following:
§ guidelines on what constitutes a cyber security incident
§ the types of incidents likely to be encountered and the expected response to each type
§ how to report cyber security incidents, internally to the organisation and externally to the Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC)
§ other parties which need to be informed in the event of a cyber security incident
§ the authority, or authorities, responsible for investigating and responding to cyber security incidents
§ the criteria by which an investigation of a cyber security incident would be requested from a law enforcement agency, the ACSC or other relevant authority
§ the steps necessary to ensure the integrity of evidence relating to a cyber security incident
§ system contingency measures or a reference to such details if they are located in a separate document.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security documentation for a system is approved by the system's authorising officer.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security documentation for a system is reviewed at least annually and includes a ‘current as at [date]’ or equivalent statement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using cryptographic equipment or software that implements an AACA, only AACAs can be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ECDH and ECDSA are used in preference to DH and DSA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using DH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a modulus of at least 1024 bits, preferably 2048 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using DSA for digital signatures, a modulus of at least 1024 bits, preferably 2048 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using elliptic curve cryptography, a curve from FIPS 186-4 is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using ECDH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a field/key size of at least 160 bits, preferably 256 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using ECDSA for digital signatures, a field/key size of at least 160 bits, preferably 256 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using RSA for digital signatures, and passing encryption session keys or similar keys, a modulus of at least 1024 bits, preferably 2048 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using RSA for digital signatures, and for passing encryption session keys or similar keys, a key pair for passing encrypted session keys that is different from the key pair used for digital signatures is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A hashing algorithm from the SHA-2 family is used instead of SHA-1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Symmetric cryptographic algorithms are not used in Electronic Codebook Mode.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3DES is used with three distinct keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Suite B and CNSSAM 02-15 algorithms are used in an evaluated configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Preference is given to using CNSSAM 02-15 algorithms over Suite B algorithms for the protection of highly classified information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using cryptographic equipment or software that implements an AACP, only AACAs can be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of SSH version 1 is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The configuration settings in the following table are implemented for the SSH daemon. (See source document for referenced table)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public key-based authentication is used for SSH connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SSH private keys are protected with a passphrase or a key encryption key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
When using logins without a passphrase for automated purposes, the following are disabled:
§ access from IP addresses that do not require access
§ port forwarding
§ agent credential forwarding
§ X11 display remoting
§ console access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using remote access without the use of a passphrase, the ‘forced command’ option is used to specify what command is executed and parameter checked is enabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When SSH-agent or other similar key caching programs are used, it is only on workstations and servers with screen locks, key caches are set to expire within four hours of inactivity, and agent credential forwarding is enabled only when SSH traversal is required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Tunnel mode is used for IPsec connections; however, if using transport mode, an IP tunnel is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The ESP protocol is used for IPsec connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: IKE is used for key exchange when establishing an IPsec connection.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using ISAKMP in IKE version 1, aggressive mode is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A security association lifetime of less than four hours, or 14400 seconds, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: HMAC-SHA256, HMAC-SHA384 or HMAC-SHA512 is used as a HMAC algorithm.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The largest modulus size possible for all relevant components in the network is used when conducting a key exchange.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PFS is used for IPsec connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of XAuth is disabled for IPsec connections using IKE version 1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Encryption software that implements an ASD Approved Cryptographic Algorithm (AACA) is used if an organisation wishes to reduce the physical storage or handling requirements for ICT equipment or media that contains sensitive information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Encryption software that has completed an ACE is used if an organisation wishes to reduce the physical storage or handling requirements for ICT equipment or media that contains classified information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: HACE is used if an organisation wishes to reduce the physical storage or handling requirements for ICT equipment or media that contains highly classified information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Encryption software used for data at rest implements full disk encryption, or partial encryption where access controls will only allow writing to the encrypted partition.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: HACE used for data at rest implements full disk encryption, or partial encryption where access controls will only allow writing to the encrypted partition.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to any encryption already in place, an AACA is used to encrypt AUSTEO and AGAO information when at rest on a system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where practical, cryptographic equipment and encryption software provides a means of data recovery to allow for circumstances where the encryption key is unavailable due to loss, damage or failure.

parts.name: statement
